docs.lead_paragraph: Is it a wake-up call for the sleeping pill market? With Wednesday's approval of Sepracor's new drug, Lunesta, a taboo in the use of sleeping pills has been broken. Lunesta is the first sleeping pill whose label will not recommend it be taken for only 7 to 10 days. The approval could clear the way for people to use Lunesta, and possibly similar drugs, for longer periods and turn sleeping pills from a market laggard into a much more widely used category of medications, sleep specialists said. ''That's going to make a lot of people more comfortable prescribing longer term, because the data exists,'' said Dr. Michael L. Perlis, an associate professor and director of the sleep research laboratory at the University of Rochester, who has consulted for Sepracor and other drug companies.

headline.main: With New Sleeping Pill, New Acceptability?

docs.abstract: Food and Drug Administration's approval of Sepracor's sleeping pill Lunesta could clear way for people to use drug, and possibly similar drugs, for longer periods and turn sleeping pills from market laggard into much more widely used category of medications; some specialists worry that new approval, and marketing push that Sepracor is planning, will lead to overuse of sleeping pills; wholesale price of Lunesta will be $3.70 per pill, about 10 percent more than leading sleeping drug Ambien; two other drugs are awaiting approval by FDA, one developed by Neurocrine Biosciences and Pfizer, and other by Takeda Pharmaceutical; chart (M)
docs.snippet: Lunesta, a new sleeping pill approved for the market on Wednesday, will be the first whose label will not recommend it be taken for only 7 to 10 days.

docs.lead_paragraph: The General Electric Company said yesterday that it expected profit to rise as much as 17 percent next year as its revamped portfolio of faster-growing businesses drives sales. Jeffrey R. Immelt, G.E.'s chief executive, said in a presentation to investors in New York that the company expected double-digit growth in 10 of its 11 main business units next year. ''We really think we have today a stronger and faster-growing G.E.,'' he said.

headline.main: G.E. Expects Profit Rise of Up to 17% Next Year

docs.abstract: General Electric Co expects profit to rise as much as 17 percent in 2005; chief executive Jeffrey R Immelt expects double-digit growth in 10 of 11 main business units next year (M)
docs.snippet: The General Electric Company said yesterday that it expected profit to rise as much as 17 percent next year as its revamped portfolio of faster-growing businesses drives sales.

docs.lead_paragraph: Pedro Martínez went on television in the Dominican Republic yesterday to say what many in New York were waiting to hear and confirm what the Mets would not. He has agreed to leave the Boston Red Sox and sign a four-year contract to pitch for the Mets. ''We got what we wanted,'' Martínez said on television, according to The Associated Press. ''The team and I are happy with everything.''

headline.main: Martínez Has One Mets Final Exam

docs.abstract: Pitcher Pedro Martinez will submit to physical examination as final step in becoming New York Mets player; photo (M)
docs.snippet: If Pedro Martínez passes Wednesday's physical, he is expected to be introduced in a news conference at Shea Stadium on Thursday.

byline.original: By LEE JENKINS; Jack Curry and Murray Chass contributed reporting for this article

docs.lead_paragraph: Teachers at 10 Roman Catholic high schools in the Archdiocese of New York called in sick yesterday to protest the terms of a new contract they say will result in a net loss of take-home pay. Nine of the 10 schools closed early. Despite wage increases included in the contact, the teachers said they would earn less because of higher health insurance contributions. Henry Kielkucki, the business manager of the teachers' union, the Lay Faculty Association, said 319 teachers participated in the job action. Joseph Zwilling, the spokesman for the archdiocese, said teachers' health contributions have not increased in 10 years. Susan Saulny (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Teachers Call In Sick To Protest Contract Offer

docs.abstract: Teachers at 10 Roman Catholic high schools in New York Archdiocese call in sick to protest terms of new contract they say will result in less take-home pay; say wage increases will be more than offset by higher health insurance contributions (S)
docs.snippet: Teachers at 10 Roman Catholic high schools in the Archdiocese of New York called in sick yesterday to protest the terms of a new contract they say will result in a net loss of take-home pay. Nine of the 10 schools closed early. Despite wage increases...

byline.original: By Susan Saulny (NYT); Compiled by Anthony Ramirez

docs.section_name: Health; Education; New York and Region

docs.lead_paragraph: Retirees who receive health benefits from their former employers saw premiums shoot up an average of 25 percent this year, a new study says. The study, issued Tuesday by the Kaiser Family Foundation and Hewitt Associates, showed a continued erosion of retiree health benefits among large employers.

headline.main: Retirees Are Paying More for Health Benefits, Study Says

docs.abstract: Kaiser Family Foundation and Hewitt Associates study finds premiums for retirees with health benefits from former employers soared average of 25 percent this year; finds 8 percent of large private employers, while continuing to provide coverage for people who have already retired, acted to end all subsidized health benefits for future retirees, and another 11 percent say they will do so in 2005; Kaiser president Drew E Altman says prospects for retiree coverage are slowly disappearing and retirees who have it will be paying more; United States Chamber of Commerce official Kate Sullivan Hare agrees; table of benefit changes (M)
docs.snippet: Retirees who receive health benefits from their former employers saw premiums shoot up an average of 25 percent this year, a new study says.

docs.lead_paragraph: COLLEGE FOOTBALL Erickson Meets With Mississippi San Francisco 49ers Coach Dennis Erickson met with Mississippi's athletic director and chancellor for two hours last night to discuss the university's vacant coaching position. Though Erickson was not offered the job, the sides agreed that their meeting in Santa Clara, Calif., went well. They plan to speak again soon, though Ole Miss's athletic director, Pete Boone, and chancellor, Robert Khayat, will interview more candidates.
docs.abstract: San Francisco 49ers coach Dennis Erickson meets with Mississippi University to discuss coaching vacancy (S)
